titleStmt.title: Fuzzy Adaptive Actuator Failure Compensation Control of Uncertain Stochastic Nonlinear Systems with Unmodeled Dynamics

analytic.title: Fuzzy Adaptive Actuator Failure Compensation Control of Uncertain Stochastic Nonlinear Systems with Unmodeled Dynamics

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper investigates the fuzzy adaptive actuator failure compensation control for a class of uncertain stochastic nonlinear systems in strict-feedback form. These stochastic nonlinear systems contain the actuator faults of both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place, unmodeled dynamics, and without direct measurements of state variables. With the help of fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions, a fuzzy state observer is established to estimate the unmeasured states. By introducing the dynamical signal and the changing supply function technique design into the backstepping control design, a robust adaptive fuzzy fault-tolerant control scheme is developed. It is proved that the proposed control approach can guarantee that all the signals of the closed-loop system are bounded in probability in the presence of the actuator failures and the unmodeled dynamics. Simulation results are provided to show the effectiveness of the control approach.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N the past decade, adaptive control design for stochastic systems has received increasing attention. Based on the It√¥ stochastic differential equation, many stochastic nonlinear system control results and the methods, such as sliding mode control [1,2], Lyapunov function approach [3] and T-S fuzzy control [4][5][6][7], have been reported in the literature. In recent years, the well-known backstepping technique has been applied to solve the control problem of stochastic nonlinear systems in strict-feedback form (see [8][9][10][11][12][13][14]). The backstepping design for stochastic single-input and single-output (SISO) nonlinear systems was investigated in [8]- [10] by introducing Quartic Lyapunov function. The robust adaptive backstepping design approaches were proposed in [11] and [12] for stochastic SISO nonlinear systems with unmodeled dynamics by changing supply function and small-gain theorem. The obtained results were extended to stochastic nonlinear largescale systems and adaptive decentralized backstepping control approaches were developed in [13] and [14]. It should be pointed out that the above mentioned results are only suitable for those stochastic nonlinear systems, in which the nonlinearities are known exactly or can be linearly parameterized. Therefore, they can not be applied to those stochastic systems with unknown nonlinear functions.

Fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) or neural networks (NNs) have been proved to be universal approximators, i.e., they can approximate any nonlinear functions. Therefore, FLSs and NNs have been widely adopted for nonlinear identification and control [15][16][17]. Using the idea of adaptive backstepping technique with the help of FLSs and NNs, many approximatorbased adaptive control approaches were developed for uncertain stochastic nonlinear systems, see for example [18]- [26] and references therein. [18]- [20] proposed adaptive fuzzy or NN state feedback control approaches for a class of SISO stochastic nonlinear systems with or without time delays; [21]- [23] developed adaptive output feedback controllers for SISO stochastic nonlinear systems without unmeasured states, while [24]- [25] investigated the adaptive fuzzy or NN decentralized output feedback stabilization problem for a class of stochastic large-scale nonlinear systems. To handle the unmodeled dynamics involved in the considered stochastic systems, [26] developed a robust adaptive output-feedback controller based on small-gain theorem, and the obtained adaptive control scheme not only guarantee the stability of the closed-loop system, but also has strong robustness to the unmodeled dynamics. The main features of these adaptive approaches are: (i) they can be used to deal with those nonlinear systems without satisfying the so-called the matching condition, and (ii) they do not require that the unknown nonlinear functions are linearly parameterized. Instead, the fuzzy logic systems or neural networks are utilized to approximate them adaptively.

Note that the aforementioned approximator-based adaptive control approaches assume that all the components in the considered stochastic nonlinear systems are in good operating conditions. In fact, there always exist some faults, such as actuators and sensors in the real processes, which often degrade the control performances and even result in the instability of the control system or even catastrophic accidents. It is thus necessary to develop a robust controller or a fault-tolerant control (FTC) scheme against actuator or sensor failures [27]- [34].

To handle the problem of nonlinear system with actuator or sensor faults, many FTC approaches have been developed, see for example [35]- [36] and references therein. [35]- [36] presented adaptive fault-tolerant controllers for linear systems with both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place actuator faults. [37]- [39] developed adaptive fault-tolerant controllers for a class of SISO nonlinear systems and MIMO nonlinear systems with the same actuator faults as in [35]- [36], while [40] and [41] developed observer-based adaptive backstepping fault-tolerant control approaches for some nonlinear systems with additive profile faults. However, the above mentioned fault-tolerant control schemes require that the considered nonlinear systems satisfy the matching conditions. To remove these limitations, [42]- [43] investigated a class of unknown SISO nonlinear strict-feedback systems with both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place actuator faults, in which fuzzy logic systems are employed to approximate the unknown functions, and based on the backstepping technique, two adaptive fuzzy backstepping FTC schemes were developed. The proposed control schemes guarantee not only the stability of the control system, but also have the robust performance of the failed system. On the basis of the results of [42] and [43], [44] proposed an adaptive fuzzy backstepping FTC scheme for a class of unknown MIMO strict-feedback nonlinear systems, and the stability of the control system was proved. However, the adaptive FTC methods described previously suffer from their requirements to measure the state variables directly. To solve the states unmeasured problem, [45] and [46] developed two fuzzy adaptive output feedback FTC methods for a class of nonlinear systems with actuator faults. It should be mentioned that the proposed adaptive control approaches are only restricted to a class of uncertain deterministic nonlinear systems, while the stochastic disturbances and the unmodeled dynamics are neglected. As stated in [39,47], the robustness of adaptive failure compensation designs with respect to system modeling errors such as unmodeled dynamics and disturbances is an important issue, thus motivated us for this study.

Inspired by previous work, this paper focuses on the fuzzy adaptive actuator failure compensation control for a class of uncertain stochastic nonlinear systems in strict-feedback form. These stochastic nonlinear systems contain the actuator faults of both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place, unmodeled dynamics, and without direct measurements of state variables. With the help of fuzzy logic systems to approximate the unknown nonlinear functions, a fuzzy state observer is established to estimate the unmeasured states. By introducing the dynamical signal and the changing supply function technique design into the backstepping control design, a robust adaptive fuzzy fault-tolerant control scheme is developed. It is shown that the proposed control approach can guarantee that all the signals of the resulting closed-loop system are bounded in probability. Comparing with the existing results, the main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows: (i) this paper first investigates an adaptive fuzzy FTC approach for a class of uncertain stochastic nonlinear systems with actuator failures and unmodeled dynamics. The same problems are also addressed in [36]- [44], however, the adaptive FTC approaches in [36]- [44] all focus on the deterministic linear or nonlinear systems. They can not be applied to control the stochastic nonlinear systems considered in this paper; (ii) the nonlinear systems under consideration in this paper include actuator failures, unmodeled dynamics and stochastic disturbances. Consequently, the proposed adaptive controller can not only accommodate the actuator faults, but also has the robustness to the unmodeled dynamics and stochastic disturbances, while the existing results in [36]- [44] can only compensate the actuator faults. (iii) The proposed fuzzy adaptive FTC approach cancels the restricted condition in [36][37][38][39][42][43][44] that all states of the controlled systems are available for measurement. Instead, a fuzzy state observer is designed to estimate the unmeasured states, and the whole control system stability is proved by using Lyaponuv function and the changing supply function methods.

div.head: II. PROBLEM FORMULATIONS AND FUZZY LOGIC SYSTEMS
A. Stochastic nonlinear system descriptions and basic assumptions
div.p: Consider the following strict-feedback stochastic nonlinear system with actuator faults and unmodeled dynamics:
div.formula: Ô£± Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£≤ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£≥ dz = q(x, z)dt dx i = (x i+1 + f i (x i ) + ‚àÜ i (x, z))dt + g i (x)dw i = 1, ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , n -1 dx n = ( T u + f n (x n ) + ‚àÜ n (x, z))dt + g n (x)dw y = x 1 (1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i = [x 1 , x 2 , ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , x i ] T ‚àà R i , i = 1, 2, ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , n (x = x n ) are the state vectors, y ‚àà R is the system output, u = [u 1 , u 2 , ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , u m ] T ‚àà R m is the input vector of the system, u i is the output of the ith actuator, = ( 1 , 2 , ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , m ) T ‚àà R m , j , j = 1, 2, ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , m are known constant vectors, z ‚àà R n0 is unmodeled dynamics, and ‚àÜ i (x, z) are dynamic disturbances. f i (x i ), i = 1, 2, ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , n
div.p: are unknown continuous nonlinear functions. q(x, z), ‚àÜ i (x, z) and g i (x) are the uncertain functions. q(x, z), ‚àÜ i (x, z) and g i (x) are locally lipschitz. w is an independent standard Brownian motion defined on a complete probability space.
The actuator faults under consideration in this paper are both lock-in-place and loss of effectiveness, which are defined by [36][37][38][39][42][43][44] as follows: Lock-in-place model:

div.head: Loss of effectiveness model:
div.formula: u i (t) = Œ∑ i v i (t), t ‚â• t i , i ‚àà {j 1 , j 2 , ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , j p } ‚à© {1, 2, ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ ‚Ä¢ , m}, Œ∑ i ‚àà [Œ∑ i , 1], 0 < Œ∑ i ‚â§ 1
div.p: (3) where v i is the input control signal which suffers from the actuator failure of loss of effectiveness model, and ≈´i is the unknown constant where the actuator u i (t) stuck at, and t i is the unknown time instants when some faults take place. Œ∑ i is the effective proportion of the actuator after losing some effectiveness, and is an unknown constant. Œ∑ i is the lower bound of Œ∑ i . When Œ∑ i is 1, the corresponding actuators work in the failures-free case.
Taking the actuator faults (2) and (3) into account, the input vector can be written as
div.formula: T u = m i=1 i {Œ∑ i v i (t) + ≈´i } (4)
div.p: Remark 1: The uniqueness of t i indicates that a failure occurs only once on the ith actuator. Hence there exists a finite T r denoting the time instant of the last failure. Such an assumption on the finite number of actuator failures can be found in many previous literature, see for example, [37][38][39][42][43][44].

Our control objective is to design an adaptive fuzzy output feedback control scheme for the system (1) with unmodeled dynamics and actuator faults to ensure that all the signals in the closed-loop system are bounded in probability, and the output y(t) converges to a small neighborhood of the origin.

To achieve the control objectives, the following assumptions are applied. Assumption 1 ([36-39,42-44]): The system (1) is so constructed that when any up to m -1 actuators stuck at some unknown places, the other(s) may lose effectiveness as (3), the closed-loop system can still be driven to achieve the control objective. Assumption 2 ([11,12]): For each 1 ‚â§ i ‚â§ n, there exist unknown positive constants p * i such that
div.formula: |‚àÜ i (x, z)| ‚â§ p * i œà i1 (y) + p * i œà i2 (|z|), |g i (x)| ‚â§ p * i œà i3 (y)
div.p: where œà i1 (y) and œà i3 (y) are known nonnegative smooth functions with œà i1 (0) = œà i3 (0) = 0. œà i2 (|z|) is a known nonnegative monotone increasing smooth functions with œà i2 (0) = 0. |‚Ä¢| and ‚Ä¢ stand for the norms of a vector and a matrix, respectively. Remark 2: Assumption 2 means that the nonlinear dynamics disturbances are nonlinear parameterized, which is commonly adopted in the control design for deterministic or stochastic nonlinear systems, for example [11,12,14,47].
By Assumption 2, there exist smooth functions œài1 , œài2 and œài3 such that

div.head: B. Fuzzy logic systems
div.p: A fuzzy logic system (FLS) consists of four parts: the knowledge base, the fuzzifier, the fuzzy inference engine working on fuzzy rules, and the defuzzifier. The knowledge base for FLS is comprised of a collection of fuzzy If-then rules of the following form: R l : If x 1 is F l 1 and x 2 is F l 2 and . . . and x n is F l n , then y is G l , l = 1, 2, . . . , N where x = (x 1 , . . . , x n ) T and y are the FLS input and output, respectively. Fuzzy sets F l i and G l are associated with the fuzzy membership functions ¬µ F l i (x i ) and ¬µ G l (y), respectively. N is the number of rules. Through singleton fuzzifier, center average defuzzification and product inference [48], the fuzzy logic system can be expressed as
div.formula: y(x) = N l=1 »≥l n i=1 ¬µ F l i (x i ) N l=1 [ n i=1 ¬µ F l i (x i )](8)
div.p: where »≥l = max y‚ààR ¬µ G l (y). Define the fuzzy basis functions as
div.formula: œï l = n i=1 ¬µ F l i (x i ) N l=1 ( n i=1 ¬µ F l i (x i )) Denoting Œ∏ T = [»≥ 1 , »≥2 , . . . , »≥N ] = [Œ∏ 1 , Œ∏ 2 , . . . , Œ∏ N ] and œï(x) = [œï 1 (x), . . . , œï N (x)
div.p: ] T , then fuzzy logic system (8) can be rewritten as
div.formula: y(x) = Œ∏ T œï(x) (9)

div.formula: sup x‚àà‚Ñ¶ f (x) -Œ∏ T œï(x) ‚â§ Œµ Definition 1 ([12]): Consider the stochastic nonlinear dif- ferential equation dx = f (x, u) + g(x)dw, if there exists C 2 function V (x), and constants c > 0, d ‚â• 0, such that V (x) ‚â§ -cV (x) + œá(|u|) + d, then
div.p: the system is inputto-state practically stable in probability (ISpS in probability), i.e., there exists a kl-function Œ≤ c (‚Ä¢, ‚Ä¢), a class k-function Œ≥ and constant d c such that, for all Œµ > 0
Definition 2 (Young's inequality [9]): For ‚àÄ(x, y) ‚àà R 2 , the following inequality holds:
div.formula: xy ‚â§ Œµ p p |x| p + 1 qŒµ q |y| q
div.p: where Œµ > 0, p > 1. q > 1, and (p -1)(q -1) = 1.

IV. FAULT-TOLERANT CONTROL DESIGN AND STABILITY ANALYSIS In this section, an adaptive fuzzy fault-tolerant control scheme will be developed by using the above fuzzy state observer and the backstepping technique [51][52][53][54][55], and the stability of the closed-loop system will be given.

div.head: A. Controller design
div.p: The adaptive backstepping controller design of this paper contains n steps; each design procedure is based on the following change of coordinates:
where Œ± i-1 are the virtual control functions to be designed in step i -1, and controller v i will be obtained in the last step.

div.p: Consider the following Lyapunov function

div.p: Then according to (64), [12] and the above facts, we can conclude that all the signal of the closed-loop system are bounded in probability for t ‚àà [0, ‚àû).

The aforementioned control design and analysis are summarized in the following theorem. Theorem 2: For stochastic nonlinear system with actuator failures and unmodeled dynamics (1), under Assumptions 1-4, the controller (46) with the fuzzy state observer (13), the intermediate controls ( 29) and ( 39), the parameter laws ( 31), ( 40), ( 48), ( 49) and ( 50) guarantee that the closed-loop system is ISpS in probability.

div.head: V. SIMULATION STUDIES
div.p: In this section, an example and comparisons are given to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive fuzzy backstepping fault-tolerant control method.
div.formula: Example: Ô£± Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£≤ Ô£¥ Ô£¥ Ô£≥ dz = q(x, z)dt dx 1 = (x 2 + f 1 (x 1 ) + ‚àÜ 1 (x, z))dt + g 1 (x)dw dx 2 = ( T u + f 2 (x 2 ) + ‚àÜ 2 (x, z))dt + g 2 (x)dw y = x 1 (69) where q(x, z) = -3z 4 + x 1 , f 1 (x 1 ) = x 1 + x 2 1 , ‚àÜ 1 (x, z) = z sin x 1 , g 1 (x) = x 2 1 sin x 1 , 1 = 2 = 0.5, f 2 (x 2 ) =
0.1 sin(0.5x 1 x 2 ), ‚àÜ 2 (x, z) = z cos(x 1 x 2 ), g 2 (x) = x 2 1 cos x 2 , u = [u 1 , u 2 ].

Then define the fuzzy basis function as From the above Figs. 1234, it is clearly that the proposed control approach can guarantee that all the signals of the considered system are bounded in probability in the presence of both actuator failures and unmodeled dynamics.
div.formula: œï i (x i ) = ¬µ F l i (x i ) 5 l=1 ¬µ F l i (x i )
div.p: In order to show that the proposed control scheme can compensate the actuator faults and unmodeled dynamics, we will discuss the following two cases.

Case 1: (Without fault-tolerant technique): For this case, the same design parameters and initial conditions are chosen the same as the above simulation. The proposed adaptive approach without fault-tolerant technique to control the system (69), the simulation results are shown in Figs. 5-6. From Figs. 56, it is clearly that the closed-loop system is unstable.

Case 2: (Without the robust term œÅ(r)): For this case, the same design parameters and initial conditions are chosen as the same as case 1. The proposed adaptive approach with From Figs. 7-8, it is clearly that the proposed control approach without the robust term œÅ(r) cannot guarantee the boundedness of the variables x 1 , x1 , x 2 , x2 and others.

div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper has developed an adaptive fuzzy control method for accommodating actuator faults in a class of uncertain stochastic nonlinear systems with both unmodeled dynamics and unmeasured states. The considered faults are modeled as both loss of effectiveness and lock-in-place. With the help of fuzzy logic systems approximating the unknown nonlinear functions, a fuzzy state observer has been designed for estimating the unmeasured states. Combining the backstepping technique with changing supply function, a novel adaptive fuzzy faults-tolerant control approach has been developed. The proposed control approach can not only guarantee that all the signals of the resulting closed-loop system are bounded in probability, but also have the robustness to the unmodeled dynamics and stochastic disturbances. Simulation results have been provided to show the effectiveness of the control approach. Future research will be concentrated on the adaptive FTC methods for uncertain MIMO stochastic nonlinear sys-
